Award.AwardTitle: GEM: The Excitation of Magnetospheric Ultra-low Frequency Waves via Solar Wind Magnetic Field Fluctuations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many studies have established a link between solar wind parameters and electron flux enhancements in the radiation belts. However, the intermediary physical mechanism(s) responsible for the observed link has yet to be definitively established. There is increasing evidence that ultra-low frequency wves within the solar wind may, at times, be responsible for electron flux enhancements in the radiation belts. This project will investigate the role that interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) fluctuations play in the generation of magnetospheric ULF pulsations within the magnetosphere. It will used controlled, numerical experiments, through the use global, three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations. Simulations can be powerful tool for studying solar wind driven ULF pulsations, since both real and synthetic solar wind conditions can be used to drive the magnetosphere. The use of synthetic, idealized solar wind configurations allows individual solar wind parameters to be isolated for detailed investigations into the magnetospheric response. In the first component of the project, MHD simulations will be driven by idealized monochromatic and broadband-type IMF fluctuations. These simulations will be conducted as a numerical experiment to fully assess the generation of magnetospheric ULF pulsations via IMF fluctuations. The results from these numerical experiments will aid in the interpretation of results from the second component of the project which will involve simulations of specific real events.

Energetic radiation belt electrons are one of the most significant hazards to such space-based technologies. This project will investigate a particular class of magnetospheric waves that may play a role in creating energetic electron flux enhancements in the outer radiation belt. Thus, this research has an important societal impact. The development of a Geospace General Circulation Model (GGCM) is a long-term goal of NSF's Geospace Environment Modeling (GEM) program and this project will contribute to such model development, by rigorously and systematically subjecting the model to IMF fluctuations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is well established that intervals of enhanced solar wind speed often lead to increases in the flux of electrons in the Earth's Van Allen radiation belts. These electrons pose a hazard for satellites that operate in this region, such as commercial and national security systems in geostationary orbit (GEO), as well as position, navigation and timing systems in medium earth orbit (e.g., GPS). Thus, it is of paramount importance that we understand why fast solar wind streams lead to enhancements in the radiation belts, which can ultimately damage and disable satellites via spacecraft charging. However, the exact physical mechanisms that link the fast solar wind streams with the radiation belts are not completely understood.

 

The overall objective of this study was to investigate the possibility that fluctuations and turbulence embedded in fast solar wind streams can couple energy into the radiation belts. The primary finding is that these solar wind fluctuations can indeed produce waves in the radiation belt region that could conceivably couple energy into the particles. Further work will be needed to compare the effectiveness of this mode of energy transfer between the solar wind and the radiation belts with other known modes, such as substorm electron injections that also accompany fast solar wind streams. This work has also demonstrated that the magnetosphere acts as a low pass filter to these upstream solar wind fluctuations, with only the lowest frequency fluctuations (in the millihertz range) passing through into the inner magnetosphere. This phenomenon has been well-established and noted in observations, but this is the first study to demonstrate this fact using numerical simulations.

 

In regards to broader impacts of the work, there were several noteworthy accomplishments. The research promoted the training and development of an early-career researcher, providing the PI with resources to attend meetings, gain exposure to the scientific community, and expand and broaden the PI's scientific expertise. The research results were disseminated broadly to the entire magnetospheric physics community, thus enhancing scientific understanding of the solar wind-magnetosphere interaction. This research also directly benefits society at large, by enabling a better understanding of the relevant space weather processes that impact our national infrastructure and national security space systems. In a similar regard, the research will enhance the capabilities of space weather modeling, by exercising numerical models in new and novel ways, which has already informed the validity and applicability of such models for space weather forecasting.
